metadata.title: Efficient, stable, and reusable Lewis acid–surfactant-combined catalyst: One-pot Biginelli and solvent-free esterification reactions

APPLICATION MOLCAA 9093 S1381-1169(14)00169-1 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.04.031 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 (a) FT-IR spectra of SLS precursor (black curve), as-prepared Ce[LS]3 catalyst (red curve), and after four runs (blue curve); (b) FT-IR spectra of as-prepared Ce[DS]3 (black curve), and kept in air for 24h (red curve). There are no position and intensity changes of Ce[LS]3 characteristic peaks after four runs. However, the weight of Ce[DS]3 increased ca. 7.4wt% (hygroscopicity) and obvious H2O characteristic peaks (marked by *) could be observed in (b) after kept in air for 24h (humidity: ca. 58%). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 XRD patterns of (a) SLS precursor, and (b) as-prepared Ce[LS]3. Fig. 3 (a) SEM image of Ce[LS]3 and (b) typical SEM-EDX results of randomly selected area in image (a). EDX results have been reproduced for three times. Fig. 4 TG curves of SLS and Ce[LS]3 in air atmosphere (25–600°C). Fig. 5 (a) The circles and squares were the ln(Ct /C 0) and Ct /C 0 versus reaction time for the esterification of myristic acid and n-butanol over Ce[LS]3 nanocomposite, respectively. C 0 and Ct were respective concentrations of myristic acid initially and at time t. (b) Ct ′/C 0′ versus reaction time for hydrolysis of butyl tetradecanoate. C 0′ and Ct ′ were the concentration of butyl tetradecanoate initially and at time t. Table 1 FT-IR assignments for SLS, as-prepared Ce[LS]3, and recycled Ce[LS]3 after four runs. Efficient, stable, and reusable Lewis acid–surfactant-combined catalyst: One-pot Biginelli and solvent-free esterification reactions Yunfeng Qiu a Hongnan Sun a Zhuo Ma b Wujiong Xia a ⁎ a State Key Lab of Urban Water Resource and Environment (SKLUWRE) & Academy of Fundamental and Interdisciplinary Science, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang 150080, China State Key Lab of Urban Water Resource and Environment (SKLUWRE) & Academy of Fundamental and Interdisciplinary Science, Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin Heilongjiang 150080 China b School of Life Science and Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, Heilongjiang 150080, China School of Life Science and Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin Heilongjiang 150080 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 451 86403760; fax: +86 451 86403760. Graphical abstract Cerium(III) trislaurylsulfonate (Ce(LS)3), a Lewis acid and surfactant combined catalyst, was prepared and characterized by SEM, SEM-EDX, XRD, NMR, FT-IR, TG, and elemental analysis. Ce(LS)3 was found to be stable and efficient to catalyze one-pot Biginelli and solvent-free esterification reactions. Furthermore, Ce(LS)3 is easy to recycle after reaction by pouring into cold water and filtration. Present work will shed deep insight into the understanding of the catalytic nature of LASCs, and extend its application in important organic transformations. Cerium(III) trislaurylsulfonate (Ce(LS)3), a Lewis acid and surfactant combined catalyst, was prepared and characterized by SEM, SEM-EDX, XRD, NMR, FT-IR, TG, and elemental analysis. Ce(LS)3 was found to be stable and efficient to catalyze one-pot Biginelli and solvent-free esterification reactions. Furthermore, Ce(LS)3 is easy to recycle after reaction by pouring into cold water and filtration. Present work will shed deep insight into the understanding of the catalytic nature of LASCs, and extend its application in important organic transformations. Keywords Lewis acid–surfactant combined catalyst Biginelli Esterification Micro reactor Solvent-free 1 Introduction Homogeneous catalytic systems usually exhibit high activity in organic reactions, however, suffer from the difficulty of recovery whereas heterogeneous catalysts are easily separated from the reaction mixture and show high catalytic activity by rational design of novel structures or components [1]. Nevertheless, heterogeneous catalytic systems still have to face the low efficiency of mass transfer in multiphase reaction [2]. To address the drawbacks of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, it is appealing to design a novel catalytic system, e.g. colloidal dispersion or reverse micelles formed by Lewis acid–surfactant combined catalysts (LASCs) [3–6]. With the unique characteristics in multifunctional catalytic property, LASCs firstly developed by Kobayashi [5,7], as one of the most widespreadly investigated catalytic system, has attracted increasing attentions during the past decades. Not only LASCs act as a Lewis acid to activate substrate molecules, but also serve as a surfactant to form stable colloidal dispersion systems with organic substrates. It is worth noting that the self-assembled process of LASCs will concentrate acid catalysts at the interface of the micelles to enhance the catalytic efficiency. To realize the best functions, exploration of LASCs designed to have specific catalytic sites, fascinating stability and practical reusability has fueled research on tailoring the combination of Lewis acids and surfactants with expectations of achieving novel or enhanced catalytic properties. So far, most studies on LASCs focused on their application in aldol [7], Diels–Alder [8,9], allylation of aldehydes [10,11], propargylamines reactions [12,13], and also in asymmetric hydroxylation [14], hydroxymethylation [15], ring-opening reactions and so on [16]. However, some of the reported LASCs are trivial to separate from the reaction system after reaction, and some have severe hygroscopicity, which would make it inconvenient for practical application [17,18]. Therefore, room still exists for developing novel LASCs and extending its application in a wider range of reactions. Additionally, few papers are addressed on the characterization of catalysts in detail. Therefore, the systematic study on the characterization of LASCs would provide deep insight into the understanding of catalytic nature, and it is also of great significance to develop a new strategy to build functional LASCs with satisfied efficiency, stability and reusability to enhance the catalytic performance in important organic transformations. Recently, Biginelli reaction has attracted considerable attentions owing to its usefulness for the synthesis of dihydropyrimidines (DHPMs) and their derivatives [19]. DHPMs are important class of compounds exhibiting pharmacological activities such as calcium channel blockers, anti-inflammatory, antitumor, α-1a-adrenergic receptor antagonist, and antihypertensive agents [20–22]. Traditional approach for HCl-catalyzed three-component cyclocondensation reaction of aldehyde, β-ketoester and urea in reflux ethanol was firstly described by Biginelli in 1893, however, there existed some drawbacks including lower yields (20%–60%), particularly for substituted aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes and long reaction time from 24 to 36h [23]. Subsequently, more complex multistep approaches could lead to higher overall yields but lack the simplicity of one-pot cyclocondensation protocols [24–26]. Previous work found that Lewis acids could catalyze one-pot Biginelli reactions, however, some of the reagents are expensive, harmful, and difficult to recover due to homogeneous phase, and some nanocomposites needed sophisticated preparation procedure [27–30]. It has been widely recognized that organic esters prepared from carboxylic acids and alcohols are important fine chemicals due to their practical application in the production of fragrances, polymers, plasticizers, biofuels, and emulsifiers [31–33]. The pioneering work of polyesterification catalyzed by dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid (DBSA) was reported by Saam et al. [34,35]. Subsequently, Landfester et al. and Takasu et al. reported that DBSA and scandium trisdodecylsulfate [Sc(DS)3] could catalyze polyesterification, respectively [36,37]. And another representative work on esterification is systematically studied by Kobayashi et al. [38]. Additionally, DBSA, copper dodecylbenzene sulfonate (CDBS) and cerium(III) trisdodecylsulfate trihydrate [Ce[DS]3·3H2O] could also effectively catalyze the solvent-free esterification reaction [17,18]. It is worth mentioning that DBSA or CDBS is trivial to separate from the reaction system after reaction, and Ce[DS]3·3H2O has severe hygroscopicity, which make it inconvenient for practical application. Herein, we present the work on synthesis and characterization of Ce(III) trislaurylsulfonate, an air stable LASCs, and its application in catalyzing one-pot Biginelli reaction and solvent-free esterification reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All reagents and solvents were commercially available and were used as such. 2.2 General remarks Morphologies and components of catalysts were performed on a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) (Model S-4300, Hitachi, Japan). Small angle X-ray diffraction (SAXRD) patterns were analyzed by Glancing-angle X-ray diffraction (GA-XRD; Philips X’Pert, Holland) using a CuKα radiation. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was recorded on a Perkin-Elmer 1710 Fourier transform spectrometer. Metal content in catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical (ICP) emission spectroscopy (Optima 5300DV). 1H NMR (400MHz) and 13C NMR (100MHz) spectra were obtained on Bruker AV-400 instrument, using CDCl3 as solvent and TMS as reference. High resolution mass spectra were recorded in an Accurate Mass Q-TOF, LC/MS, Agilent Technologies 6520. Analyses of esters were measured by gas chromatography (GC) on a Tianmei GC-5790 chromatograph with FID detector, equipped with a polar polyethylene glycol column BP 20, 12m, 0.32i.d. and film thickness of 0.25μm. Oven temperature ranged from 200 to 250°C, using a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1. 2.3 Catalysts preparation Cerium(III) trislaurylsulfonate monohydrate (Ce[SO3C12H25]3 or denoted as Ce[LS]3) was synthesized according to a published procedure as follows [39]. (i) 2.94g of sodium laurylsulfonate (SLS, Aladdin, 98%) were added to 50mL of distilled water and dissolved at 60°C in a water bath; (ii) 5.59g of cerium(III) chloride heptahydrate (CeCl3·7H2O, Aladdin, 99%) were completely dissolved in 50mL of distilled water at room temperature and warmed up at 60°C in a water bath; (iii) after dissolution, the CeCl3 solution was added under stirring, and the resulted slurry was stirred for 30min. The white precipitate was filtered, recrystallized with hot distilled water for 3 times, and dried in vacuum at room temperature (25°C) overnight. Other catalysts were prepared following the similar procedure, and denoted as La[LS]3, Fe[LS]3, Co[LS]3, Ni[LS]2, Cu[LS]2, Zn[LS]2, and Mn[LS]2. Ce[DS]3 was also synthesized by the similar procedure except using sodium dodecylsulfate (SDS) instead of sodium laurylsulfonate (SLS) as starting material. 2.4 General procedure for the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidinones/thiones To a mixture of aldehyde 1 (1mmol), ethyl acetoacetate 2 (1.5mmol) and urea or thiourea 3 (1.5mmol) in a round-bottomed flask (10mL), M[LS] x (10mol%) and one drop concentrated HCl in ethanol (3mL) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 80°C for 6h in an oil-bath (Table 1 ). At the end of reaction (monitored by TLC), the mixture was poured into crushed ice/water mixture. Stirring was maintained for 5min, and the solid mixture was filtered, washed with cold water (2× 15mL). Subsequently, the solid cake was dissolved in acetone, and the undissolved catalyst could be easily filtered. The acetone phase was collected and dried by rotavap, then the crude powder was recrystallized from ethyl acetate/n-hexane or ethanol to afford pure product. All products were identified by comparing their spectral and physical data with those of authentic samples. Used acetone could be recycled for next experiment, which was found to have no influence on reaction yield. 2.5 General procedure for the synthesis of esters Carboxylic acid (1mmol), alcohol (6mmol) and 5mol% catalyst were added to a 10ml round-bottom flask with a reflux condenser. The reaction mixture was continuously stirred using a magnetic stirrer (800rpm) at 80°C in an oil-bath for an appropriate time, and the progress of reaction was monitored by TLC. At the end of reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and poured into water. Afterwards, the filtered cake was purified by chromatography on silica gel using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (20:1) as eluent to give the pure product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 FT-IR analysis FT-IR characterization has proven to be a powerful technique for the study of components and structure of catalyst including organic segments. Fig. 1 shows the FT-IR spectra of SLS, as-prepared Ce[LS]3, and after four runs. As summarized in Table 1, peaks at 2957, 2873, and 1378cm−1 observed from Fig. 1 (black curve) of SLS, were ascribed to stretching and formation vibration of CH3, respectively [18,40]. Meanwhile, stretching vibration of CH2 was found at 2921, 2851cm−1. The peak centered at 1415 and 722cm−1 were associated with wagging vibration of α-CH2 and rocking vibration of CH2 , respectively. These bands were assigned to the characteristic peaks of alkyl chain in SLS. Comparatively, Ce[LS]3 catalyst shows similar characteristic peaks of alkyl chain, as illustrated in Fig. 1 (red curve) and Table 1. The spectrum of SLS shows bands at 533, 553, and 619cm−1 corresponding to the bending vibration of SO3 −, and peaks at 1065, 1180, and 1204cm−1 ascribing to the stretching vibration of SO3 − [41]. However, the bending vibration of SO3 − in Ce[LS]3 located at 522, 544, 605, and 621cm−1, and the stretching vibration of SO3 − were positioned at 1069, 1081, 1166, and 1186cm−1 [42]. The position and intensity of SO3 − was found to be very sensitive to the changes of chemical environments caused by metal ions coordination [41]. Comparing FT-IR spectra of SLS and Ce[LS]3, we found that the bending and stretching vibration of SO3 − degenerated obviously, and positions changed greatly. We assumed that the intense shifting and splitting of both symmetric and asymmetric modes could be ascribable to the interaction of laurylsulfonate anions with Ce(III) cations. 3.2 XRD analysis In order to further study the structure of Ce[LS]3, small angle XRD was performed for both Ce[LS]3 and SLS. As shown in Fig. 2 , strong reflections of Ce[LS]3 were observed at lower diffraction angles at 2θ =2.36°, 2.65°, 4.66°, 5.26°, 6.99° and 7.9°, corresponding to 3.74, 3.33, 1.89, 1.68, 1.26 and 1.12nm calculated by Bragg's law, respectively. Concomitantly, the characteristic peaks of SLS are located at respective 2θ =2.39°, 2.59°, 3.16°, 4.79°, and 7.15°, ascribing to 3.69, 3.41, 2.79, 1.84 and 1.24nm. XRD patterns of Ce[LS]3 and SLS are regarded as characteristics of lamellar arrangements. According to Bragg equation, the interplanar spacing (d hkl ) illustrated a periodicity of 3.74nm for Ce[LS]3 and 3.69nm for SLS. It has been generally known that four crystalline phases of SDS all have similar bilayer structures, in which the dodecylsulfate molecules are stacked in a head to head, tail to tail mode, alternating alkyl chains and sulfate head-group [43]. SLS and SDS have almost identical chemical structures. Dias et al. reported that the interplanar spacing are 3.76nm in the crystal morphology of Ce[DS]3, which is dominated by the (0 0 1) face [18]. In present case, the interplanar spacing is 3.74nm and 3.69nm for Ce[LS]3 and SLS, which agree with the reported value as abovementioned. Therefore, we assumed that (0 0 1) face is the dominant face in both Ce[LS]3 and SLS. As also confirmed in Fig. 1, the relative intensity and position of infrared regions attributing to the alkyl chain vibration modes (see Table 1) for Ce[LS]3 and SLS are nearly identical. The results illustrated that the structure of Ce[LS]3 might be bilayered arrangement, and packed in a head to head, tail to tail mode. However, the interlayer distance of d 001 is 3.76nm, a little bigger than that of SLS, which probably ascribed to the bigger radius of CeIII or less tilting angle of alkyl chains from (0 0 1) plane [44]. 3.3 Morphology and composition study SEM image of Ce[LS]3 in Fig. 3 shows that agglomerates range from 2μm to 15μm in length along longer axis, which are consisted of irregular sheet-like structures. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping images of Ce, S, C, and O taken on the same sample show that Ce, S, C, and O are evenly distributed in material (data not shown). The observed Ce and S atomic ratio of 0.54:1.52 is close to 1:3, further confirming the chemical composition of Ce[LS]3. In addition, Table 2 shows the element analysis of as-prepared catalyst. The content of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, sulfur, and cerium was consistent with the expected theoretical values for Ce[C12H25O3S]3·H2O, which was further verified by TGA measurement. 3.4 TGA analysis As demonstrated in Fig. 4 , the total weight loss of SLS from 125 to 463°C was 73.1%, which is related to the elimination of alkyl chains and SO3 (weight loss expected: 73.9%) [45]. The remained product is stable up to 600°C, and the weight of residues left after calcinations (26.9%) attributed to expected value for the formation of Na2SO4 (26.1%). Comparatively, the decomposition of Ce[LS]3 in air atmosphere takes place from 128 to 500°C, which is associated with the loss of water molecules, alkyl chains and SO3 [46]. The completely decomposed residue was CeO2 corresponding to an observed loss of 81.2% (weight loss expected: 81.0%). 3.5 NMR study Fig. S1 depicts the 1H NMR (400MHz) of as-prepared Ce[LS]3. It was observed that the chemical shifts emerged at d =0.87ppm (triplet, 9H, and J =6.8Hz); 1.25–1.29ppm (m, 54H); 1.52–1.60ppm (m, 6H); and 2.41ppm (triplet, 6H, and J =8.0Hz) in DMSO-d 6. In DMSO, water signal appears at d =3.40ppm, and is related to H2O molecules from catalyst and solvent. 13C NMR (100MHz) spectrum of Ce[LS]3 in DMSO-d 6 exhibits characteristic peaks of laurylsulfonate compound at δ =13.88, 22.02, 25.00, 28.36, 28.64, 28.84, 28.87, 28.94, 28.96, 28.99, 31.22, and 51.45ppm. 4 Catalytic reactions studies 4.1 Biginelli reaction Preliminarily, we employed as-prepared Ce[LS]3 as a catalyst in one-pot reaction of benzaldhyde (1mmol), ethyl acetoacetate (1.5mmol) and urea (1.5mmol). To our delight, 3,4-dihydropyrimidinone was obtained in 83% yield in the presence of Ce(LS)3 (2mol%) and the value of TOF is 5.1875h−1 (Table 3 , entry 1). Further studies revealed that the yields were improved to as high as 98% at quantitative conversion when the amount of catalyst increased from 5 to 20mol% (Table 3, entries 2–4). In comparison, we also prepared a series of catalysts and subjected them to the experiments. As it can be seen, moderate to good yields, but a little lower than that of Ce[LS]3, were observed owing to their relatively strong Lewis acid activity (Table 3, entries 5–12). The application of C12H25SO3Na and SDBS led to 82% and 84% yield, respectively (Table 3, entries 13 and 14). However, these homogeneous systems suffer from the difficulty in recovery, which is against the basic principle of green chemistry [47–49]. Different solvents, such as THF, CH3CN, acetone, DMF, etc. were also screened in the reaction affording the product in 9%–75% yields, as shown in Table S1 [50]. It is noteworthy that the Biginelli reaction catalyzed by Ce[LS]3 (10mol%) in water was also tested, and only gave moderate yield of 45%, and simultaneously had 4.5% of Hantzsch byproduct, which has been reported in previous literature [51–53]. However, the reaction performed in neat reaction can afforded 83% yield. With this optimized reaction conditions in hand we tended to investigate the generality and limitation of this method. Therefore, the reaction of various aromatic/heterocyclic aldehydes, 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and urea or thiourea were explored under this protocol to produce a series of structurally diverse DHPMs, and the results are summarized in Table 4 . The reactions proceeded very smoothly in reflux ethanol with 10mol% Ce[LS]3 and were completed within 6h. The main characteristics of reactions are good to excellent activity in most cases, giving 73–97% isolated yields. Present catalytic system was tolerant to the variation in all three components, and showed slight loss of activity after 4 runs. Aromatic aldehydes carrying either electron-donating groups (EDG) or electron-withdrawing groups (EWG) in the ortho, meta, and para positions are well tolerated in reaction without significant impact on yields. More importantly, aldehydes bearing two different substituents (entry 9) with steric hindrance also afforded the corresponding product in 76% yield, which, however, was obtained in poor yield in classical Biginelli reaction conditions [23]. We also found that ethyl acetoacetate, ethyl benzoylacetate, and methyl acetoacetate all could be used to synthesize the derivatives (entries 1–10, 15–19). Recently, synthesis of DHPMs containing sulfur atom attracted much attention due to their biological activity, such as monastrol, which is a new class of anticancer agents acting as cell division (mitosis) blockers [54]. Therefore, thiourea was applied in the reaction instead of urea which successfully led to the corresponding DHPMs in good to excellent yields (entries 11–14). To test the stability and recyclability of the catalyst, it was filtered and washed with acetone and distilled water after reaction, and then dried in vacuum at r.t. overnight. 1H NMR (data not shown) and FT-IR results (Fig. 1a and Table 1) proved the chemical shifts and main characteristic peaks of Ce[LS]3 maintained after four runs. It should also be pointed out that recovered catalysts exhibited 4% loss of activity after four runs (Table 4, entry 1). Importantly, the catalyst did not lose its activity obviously and gave 92% yield after storage in air for one year (Table 4, entry 1). Most researchers have investigated the mechanism of the Biginelli reaction, and regarded the key intermediate as N-acyliminium ion formed in situ by the reaction of aldehyde with urea. In present work, we assumed that this process took place in reverse micelles constructed by Ce[LS]3 in ethanol. 4.2 Solvent-free esterification Generally, esterification reaction is accelerated by using water separation or adding molecular sieves. Researchers found that dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid (DBSA) or dodecylbenzene sulfonate (CDBS) could form reverse micelles to catalyze esterification reaction [17,55]. These micelles have a hydrophilic interior, thus esters generated during reaction are effectively removed from the droplets due to intrinsic hydrophobicity. Nevertheless, water molecules are staying in the interior of micelles [38]. Furthermore, self-assembled process will concentrate acid catalysts at the interface of droplets. Based on these two aspects, the reaction equilibrium would shift toward the desired side of esters. It should be noted that DBSA or CDBS suffer from their recovery after reaction. We therefore further investigate the catalytic performance of Ce[LS]3 in esterification reaction to extend its wider application. As depicted in Table 5 , in the presence of 10mol% of Ce[LS]3, myristic acid, palmitic acid or stearic acid reacted with methanol smoothly, giving the corresponding esters in good yields (entries 1, 9, 10), which is an important reaction in biodiesel production. In addition, we also found that Ce[LS]3 was tolerant to other alcohols with different alkyl chains length (entries 2–4), cyclic alcohol (entry 5), and aromatic alcohols (entries 6–8). α,β-Unsaturated carboxylic acids also reacted smoothly with n-butanol giving moderate to good yields. The resulted α,β-unsaturated esters were proved to possess various pharmacological activities including antioxidant, antimicrobial and anticancer activities, besides extensive use in other synthetic applications [56–59]. Furthermore, Ce[LS]3 shows high stability in solvent-free esterification, and gives 91% yield when applying in esterification of myristic acid and n-butanol after five runs. Fig. 5 shows that the plots of the concentration of myristic acid versus time in the presence of 10mol% Ce[LS]3. It was obvious that the concentration of myristic acid decreased due to the esterification with n-butanol. The plots of ln(C 0/C t ) versus time yielded good linear correlations as indicated in Fig. 5a, revealing that the esterification followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. The values of pseudo-first-order constants and turnover frequency (TOF) were 0.42h−1 and 1.58h−1. And this TOF is two times bigger than that reported previously [17]. We hypothesized that the carbonyl oxygen of the carboxylic group combines with CeIII of Ce[LS]3 to form an activated complex [17]. Subsequently, an intermediate was formed by the attack of nucleophilic alcohol. Finally, the intermediate eliminates water to afford the product ester. During this process, the reverse micelles with hydrophilic interior assembled by Ce[LS]3 serve as micro-reactors, which automatically separate water from ester like mini-separators. Separation of water from ester not only avoids hydrolysis of ester (see Fig. 5b), but also rapidly promotes the equilibrium reaction toward ester. Thus, azeotropic distillation equipment or molecular sieves is not required. 5 Conclusion In summary, we have successfully developed an efficient, air stable and reusable catalyst for one-pot synthesis of dihydropyrimidin-ones or thiones and solvent-free esterification. More importantly, Ce[LS]3 could catalyze the Biginelli reaction in homogeneous during reaction and be easily recovered by filtration after pouring into cold water after reaction. In the case of esterification reaction, not only avoids this micro-reactor hydrolysis of ester, but also rapidly promotes the equilibrium reaction toward ester. coredata.dc:description: Cerium(III) trislaurylsulfonate (Ce(LS)3), a Lewis acid and surfactant combined catalyst, was prepared and characterized by SEM, SEM-EDX, XRD, NMR, FT-IR, TG, and elemental analysis. Ce(LS)3 was found to be stable and efficient to catalyze one-pot Biginelli and solvent-free esterification reactions. Furthermore, Ce(LS)3 is easy to recycle after reaction by pouring into cold water and filtration. Present work will shed deep insight into the understanding of the catalytic nature of LASCs, and extend its application in important organic transformations.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient, stable, and reusable Lewis acid–surfactant-combined catalyst: One-pot Biginelli and solvent-free esterification reactions
